citation.article-title: Clostridium aerotolerans sp. nov., a xylanolytic bacterium from corn stover and from the rumina of sheep fed corn stover.

p.s: Description of Clostridium aerotolerans sp. nov.
Clostridium aerotolerans (ae.ro.to'le.rans Gr. masc. n. aer, air, gas; L. v. tolerare, to endure, to put up with; L. neut. part. adj. aerotolerans, air-enduring)
Cells grow under strictly anaerobic conditions and also in agar or liquid medium free of added reducing agent.
They also grow in a shallow layer of liquid medium (5 ml in 50-ml Erlenmeyer flasks loosely covered with sterile caps) free of added reducing agent but exposed to air.
In this medium growth is observed within 7 or 8 h after inoculation and can be seen as a turbid layer on the bottom of the flasks where the medium is reduced with respect to resazurin.
About 15 min after gentle shaking of the flasks to suspend the bacteria, the resazurin is almost completely reduced.

On standing, the upper layer of medium again becomes at least partly oxidized with respect to resazurin, and after incubation for a further period of 16 to 17 h, growth appears as a dense layer on the bottom of the flasks with only the uppermost layer of medium showing some color due to oxidized resazurin.
At this stage vigorous shaking is required to dislodge the bacteria from the bottom of the flask where most growth has occurred.
Incubation in a shaking water bath of inoculated medium prepared in the same way does not produce any growth, and the medium is not reduced with respect to resazurin even after 3 days.
Cells from 16-h cultures on agar slopes containing either cellobiose or xylan are gram negative.
Very little, if any, stain is adsorbed if crystal violet is the only stain used, Vegetative cells are straight rods often with somewhat pointed ends (Fig. 1A and B).
They usually occur singly.
Their width varies from 0.4 to 0.6 μm, and their length is about 1.5 to 3.0 μm and sometimes more.
Cells are motile by peritrichous flagella (Fig. 1B).
Spores stain green with malachite green.
They are terminal and distend the cells where they are formed (Fig. 1C).
They are slightly oval and measure about 0.6 by 0.8 μm.
After incubation for 3 days on films of glucose (0.5%) agar medium in roll bottles, surface colonies are round with smooth or almost smooth edges.
They are convex and appear translucent at the edges to semitranslucent and light brown at the center.
Colonies are up to 2.5 mm wide.
Submerged colonies are lens shaped and appear brown when viewed from the side.

Surface colonies in xylan (3%) agar medium in roll bottles appear similar to those that develop on glucose medium and are surrounded by a clear zone (1 to 3 cm in diameter) due to the dissolution of xylan.
In addition, there are large spreading colonies with lobate edges and thin translucent growth.
Dissolution of xylan extends to several millimeters beyond the outer periphery of these colonies.
Submerged, lens-shaped colonies give rise to clearing zones of 1 cm or more in diameter.
The four strains are saccharoclastic and show little, if any, growth in media containing peptone and yeast extract but without added carbohydrate.
Peptone and yeast extract can replace rumen fluid in medium containing carbohydrate.
Media containing rumen fluid as the sole source of growth factors support moderate growth.
For two strains tested (X8A62 and X2) absorbance at 578 nm (1-cm path length) of medium containing clarified rumen fluid and cellobiose increases by about 0.3 U in 16 h.
If this medium is supplemented with peptone (10 g/liter), the absorbance increases to about 0.6 U over the same period.
If the medium is further supplemented with yeast extract (5 g/liter), the absorbance reached after 16 h is about 0.9 U.
The last value is also obtained when the medium is enriched with only the yeast extract (without the peptone).
Incubation for longer periods does not yield appreciably higher absorbance readings.
A medium containing (apart from minerals and Na2CO3) only glucose (5 g/liter), yeast extract (5 g/liter), cysteine hydrochloride.
H2O (0.125 g/liter), and Na2S⋄9H2O (0.125 g/liter) gives a maximum absorbance of about 1.8 U.
This medium was used to assess the approximate optimum growth temperature of strain X8A62.
The maximum absorbance (between 1.4 and 1.8 U) is attained after about 24 h at 38T, 30 h at 30°C, and 60 h at 22°C.
After 60 h at 15°C, absorbance is about 0.1 U.
Growth does not occur at 45°C.
A wide range of carbohydrate energy sources is fermented (Table 1) with the final pH not falling below 5.2.
Xylan is fermented to formic, acetic, and lactic acids, ethanol, hydrogen, and carbon dioxide (Table 2).
Acetylmethylcarbinol is not produced.
None of the four strains liquefies gelatin or digests casein, and no H2 S is formed from peptone or from sulfate reduction.
Neither indole nor α-methylindole is produced.
There is no indication that the bacteria possess urease, catalase, or enzymes for reducing nitrate.
Some lipase activity was exhibited by all four strains.
The G + C content of the DNA is about 40 mol% for all four strains.
All nine values fell between 39 and 41 mol%.
The type strain is X8A62 (ATCC 43524), isolated from the rumen of a sheep.
